ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None.
Zoom discussion seminar.
all online

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Better way to think through connections between authors and developments in political philosophy
I think it provided an opportunity to think critically about a few important texts, which is very valuable.
Learned about various western social and political thinkers through close analyses of their works. Discussions allowed for enriched understandings of their perspectives.
I learned a broad survey of western canon philosophers.
Learned about different philosophers and  how to apply their philosophies to modern day or historical events
Close reading of in-depth philosophical and political texts. Applying ideas of antiquity to problems of modernity.
Basic knowledge on how to approach dense texts, important overviews on canonical theories on politics and ethics.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Instructor + readings were huge strengths of the course. Reading questions when posed ahead of time were good. Emphasis on close reading gave me a greater appreciation for the readings

I mean zoom makes it difficult but I dont see a ton of room for improvement. Perhaps more conversation about the common threads and broad significance of the texts would be useful, rather than reconstructing the texts arguments themselves.
The course is quite well-structured. The works of various readers are presented in relation to one another and to ethics, politics and economics.

Strengths - very in depth, Professor Kapustin is amazing and offers great feedback on papers
Weaknesses - seminars are mostly lecture format which is hard in the online form

S: Prof. Kapustin does a great job of explaining the philosophies assigned for reading. The readings chosen are interesting and relevant.

W: Discussion could benefit from more room for questions rather than summarizing readings amongst students. This would help avoid repetitive responses by students to Prof. Kapustin's questions.

Great course taught by a great professor. I think it definitely suffered with the Zoom format and would have been much more engaging in person. Professor Kapustin is a fantastic teacher but his style didn't translate super well to Zoom. Additionally student's participation definitely suffered as a result of the Zoom format.

I loved the lecture-based approach to the seminar. With intimidating texts like these, it was helpful to have a grounding perspective to base other opinions on seeing as the abstract concepts are often interpreted in different ways.

The course could be improved a bit with better time management of discussions or a readjustment of the syllabus. It's a lot of material to cover and we frequently fell behind the schedule on the syllabus which made knowing what exactly we were going to be actually discussing in class on a given week difficult. Oftentimes, I would find myself doing the reading but not discussing most of it until the following week, though by then my thoughts weren't as fresh, and my mind was not in the same headspace, so talking about the readings became difficult.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Reading responses good. Perhaps making sure to take a short break during class or otherwise checking in regarding student participation during class would be helpful
I think zoom seminars work ok. The more engagement the better.
The virtual learning format was easy to follow.

Professor Kapustin was kind and lenient with deadlines which helped encourage students to really put their best foot forward. More participation in seminars and class discussions would have been helpful.

The seminar was small enough to allow discussion and participation of all students. No need for breakout rooms. Prof. Kapustin did well to open up room for discussion and then overview what was being said, clarifying important concepts.
See above.
Lecture-based approach was great  just wished I could've experienced it in person.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes - very enlightening course
Yeah for sure! Its mostly interesting. I think it would be especially interesting if you were coming to each text for the first time.
Yes!!
Yes. Prof. Kapustin is great, he cares about his students and he is very knowledgeable about the subject. I would recommend to anyone hoping to study political philosophy.
Yes
I would for those interested in a deep dive into historical, Western thought of EP&E.
